{{dda|2004|4|9|1942|1|21|mf=y}} | origin = | instrument = [[Guitar]], [[harmonica]], [[Human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[Detroit blues]], [[electric blues]] | years_active = Early 1960s–2003 | label = [[JSP Records]] | associated_acts = | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''The Butler Twins''' were an [[United States|American]] [[Detroit blues]] and [[electric blues|electric]] [[blues]] [[duet (music)|duo]], comprising the [[twin]]s Clarence (January 21, 1942 – December 22, 2003) and Curtis Butler (January 21, 1942 – April 9, 2004). Long-time semi-professional performers in the local blues scene in [[Detroit]], they gained international recognition following the [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] of three albums in the late 1990s. Their best known track was "The Butler's Boogie." ==Biography== Clarence and Curtis Butler were born seconds apart, and grew up in [[Florence, Alabama|Florence]], [[Alabama]]. Their father, Willie "Butch" Butler, was noteworthy as a local guitar player, and with his harmonica playing partner, Raymond Edwards, both proved useful tutors.{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher= Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | page= 98 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}} By the age of seven the twins were proficient enough musicians to win a [[talent contest]], and played in the abandoned house where [[W. C. Handy]] once lived. They were in the middle of a family of sixteen [[sibling]]s, and the twins put together their first [[musical ensemble]] at the age of 14, and two years later started to tour the [[Southern United States]].[http://www.metrotimes.com/metropolis/sonic/artistprofile.asp?id=274 ]{{dead link|date=January 2014}} They relocated to Detroit in 1960, and worked in automobile assembly plants. By night they were part of the local [[nightclub]] scene. Clarence Butler supplied [[harmonica]] and [[Human voice|vocals]], while Curtis Butler played [[rhythm guitar]], and they sat in with other musicians, until the local blues scene faded away in the late 1960s. In the early 1980s, with the Butler Twins still in residence, they were lauded as blues survivors.{{cite web|author=Richard Skelly |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/the-butler-twins-mn0000627556/biography |title=The Butler Twins | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29}} The [[London]], [[England]], based [[JSP Records]] [[record label|label]] issued two [[album]]s; ''Not Gonna Worry About Tomorrow'' (May 1995) and ''Pursue Your Dreams'' (May 1996). The relative success led to [[concert tour|tours]] across the [[United States|US]], [[Canada]] and [[Europe]]. The Twins, as they became referred to in the blues community, became more famous overseas than in their own country. In 2000, the [[Detroit Music Awards]] gave the Outstanding Blues Writer award to Clarence Butler. The Butler Twins were granted Music Achiever status by the [[Alabama Music Hall of Fame]].[http://www.alamhof.org/butlertwins.html ]{{dead link|date=January 2014}} Clarence Butler died after a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]] on December 22, 2003, in [[Hamtramck, Michigan|Hamtramck]], Michigan.{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2003b.html |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 2003 July to December |publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29}} Curtis Butler died just over three months later on April 9, 2004.{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2004.html |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 2004 January To June |publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29}} ==Discography== *''Not Gonna Worry About Tomorrow'' (1995) - [[JSP Records|JSP]] *''Pursue Your Dreams'' (1996) - JSP *''The Butler's Boogie'' (2000) - [[live album]] - Orchard{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/the-butler-twins-mn0000627556/discography |title=The Butler Twins | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29}} ==See also== *[[List of Detroit blues musicians]] *[[List of electric blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Butler Twins, The}} [[Category:American blues guitarists]] [[Category:American blues harmonica players]] [[Category:American blues musical groups]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:American musical groups]] [[Category:Detroit blues musicians]] [[Category:Electric blues musicians]] [[Category:Family musical groups]] [[Category:Musicians from Alabama]] [[Category:Sibling musical duos]] [[Category:Songwriters from Alabama]] [[Category:Songwriters from Michigan]] [[Category:Twin people from the United States]]
